title: Lawmakers: Jobless-Benefits Fight Won’t Derail Budget Deal
content:
WASHINGTON -- Democrats ’ push to extend emergency benefits for unemployed workers won ’ t derail bipartisan budget talks that could produce a deal this week , lawmakers said Sunday .
Democrats have been pressing to continue benefits for the long-term unemployed beyond the program ’ s Dec. 28 expiration , but won ’ t demand its extension as part of the effort to reach a fiscal agreement , Sen. Richard Durbin ( D. , Ill. ) said Sunday on ABC ’ s `` This Week . ''
“ I do n't think we 've reached that point where we 've said this is it ; take it or leave it , ” said Mr. Durbin .
Senate Budget Committee Chairwoman Patty Murray ( D. , Wash. ) and House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan ( R. , Wis. ) haven ’ t yet “ closed the deal ” on an agreement to keep the government running beyond Jan. 15 , but are “ moving in the right direction , ” Mr. Durbin said .
Sen . Rob Portman ( R. , Ohio ) , a member of the broader group negotiating the budget deal , said the GOP ’ s concern over extending the unemployment benefits was its $ 25 billion price tag .
“ It 's an additional cost within this budget agreement . I think the thought always that would be handled separately , ” Mr. Portman said Sunday on ABC . Several Democrats are pushing to vote on an extension this week in the Senate , though how to pay for it remains an issue . Congress has opted at times in the past to renew the 2008 benefits without offsetting their cost through tax increases or spending cuts .
On the budget front , officials close to the talks have said Ms. Murray and Mr. Ryan are closing in on a deal that would allow spending of roughly $ 1 trillion in each of the next two years . The mid-October agreement to end the partial government shutdown tasked the budget group with coming up with a budget plan for the rest of the 2014 fiscal year by Friday .
Mr. Portman said he expected a budget deal could be accomplished “ over the next couple days . ”
Lawmakers have been working to craft a compromise that would ease across-the-board spending cuts due to take effect in January , known as the sequester , and replace them with a mix of increased fees and cuts in mandatory spending programs .
Even with a modest budget deal appearing more likely , lawmakers remained at odds over other policies , including whether to raise the federal minimum wage above its current level of $ 7.25 per hour . Mr. Obama pushed for raising the wage last week in a speech last week , vowing to focus his final three years in office on income inequality .
But Republicans have argued increasing the minimum wage could limit companies ’ ability to hire new workers .
“ Republicans as a whole agree there ought to be a minimum wage , and it ought to be fair . But we 're very concerned about jobs , ” Mr. Portman said , noting that he had recently been to a fast-food restaurant that employed a digital display to take his order , rather than a cashier . “ If you raise the minimum wage too high , you 're going to have not more jobs but fewer jobs . ”
The issue of increased automation in fast-food was summed up colorfully earlier this year in a newspaper ad from the Employment Policies Institute , a right-leaning think tank , which argued that robots could bump out human workers if the minimum wage is raised .
Mr. Durbin said research has undercut the argument that bumping up the minimum wage would destroy jobs . “ The facts and statistics do not back it up , ” he said , noting that Congress used to routinely increase the wage on a bipartisan basis “ to protect those hardworking Americans who could n't keep up with the expenses of life . ”

Democrats have been pressing to continue benefits for the long-term unemployed beyond the program’s Dec. 28 expiration, but won’t demand its extension as part of the effort to reach a fiscal agreement, Sen. Richard Durbin (D., Ill.) said Sunday on ABC’s "This Week."

“I don't think we've reached that point where we've said this is it; take it or leave it,” said Mr. Durbin.

Senate Budget Committee Chairwoman Patty Murray (D., Wash.) and House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan (R., Wis.) haven’t yet “closed the deal” on an agreement to keep the government running beyond Jan. 15, but are “moving in the right direction,” Mr. Durbin said.

Sen. Rob Portman (R., Ohio), a member of the broader group negotiating the budget deal, said the GOP’s concern over extending the unemployment benefits was its $25 billion price tag.

“It's an additional cost within this budget agreement. I think the thought always that would be handled separately,” Mr. Portman said Sunday on ABC. Several Democrats are pushing to vote on an extension this week in the Senate, though how to pay for it remains an issue. Congress has opted at times in the past to renew the 2008 benefits without offsetting their cost through tax increases or spending cuts.

On the budget front, officials close to the talks have said Ms. Murray and Mr. Ryan are closing in on a deal that would allow spending of roughly $1 trillion in each of the next two years. The mid-October agreement to end the partial government shutdown tasked the budget group with coming up with a budget plan for the rest of the 2014 fiscal year by Friday.

Mr. Portman said he expected a budget deal could be accomplished “over the next couple days.”

Lawmakers have been working to craft a compromise that would ease across-the-board spending cuts due to take effect in January, known as the sequester, and replace them with a mix of increased fees and cuts in mandatory spending programs.

Even with a modest budget deal appearing more likely, lawmakers remained at odds over other policies, including whether to raise the federal minimum wage above its current level of $7.25 per hour. Mr. Obama pushed for raising the wage last week in a speech last week, vowing to focus his final three years in office on income inequality.

But Republicans have argued increasing the minimum wage could limit companies’ ability to hire new workers.

“Republicans as a whole agree there ought to be a minimum wage, and it ought to be fair. But we're very concerned about jobs,” Mr. Portman said, noting that he had recently been to a fast-food restaurant that employed a digital display to take his order, rather than a cashier. “If you raise the minimum wage too high, you're going to have not more jobs but fewer jobs.”

The issue of increased automation in fast-food was summed up colorfully earlier this year in a newspaper ad from the Employment Policies Institute, a right-leaning think tank, which argued that robots could bump out human workers if the minimum wage is raised.

Mr. Durbin said research has undercut the argument that bumping up the minimum wage would destroy jobs. “The facts and statistics do not back it up,” he said, noting that Congress used to routinely increase the wage on a bipartisan basis “to protect those hardworking Americans who couldn't keep up with the expenses of life.”
